title: 111_hr3818
content: The Act is titled the "Private Fund Investment Advisers Registration Act of 2009" and includes definitions for various terms. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to define "private fund" as an issuer exempt from being an investment company under certain sections. It also defines a "foreign private fund adviser" as an investment adviser without a US office, fewer than 15 US clients, and assets under management below a specified amount. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to define a "private fund" as an issuer exempt from being an investment company under certain sections. The Commission may deem appropriate in the public interest or for the protection of investors. Elimination of private adviser exemption; limited exemption for foreign private fund advisers; limited intrastate exemption. Section 203(b) of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to include exceptions for investment advisers to private funds and foreign private fund advisers. Additionally, a new category is added for investment advisers advising small business investment companies. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 allows entities to qualify for a license under certain conditions, including those related to licensed small business investment companies. SEC. 4. COLLECTION OF SYSTEMIC RISK DATA. Section 204 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to require investment advisers to maintain records and file reports regarding private funds advised by them for the protection of investors and assessment of systemic risk. The Commission can share this information with the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System and other entities responsible for systemic risk. Investment advisers must maintain records and file reports for private funds they advise, including details on assets under management, leverage, credit risk exposures, trading positions, and other information deemed necessary by the Commission and the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System. The Commission may require private fund advisers to report additional information as deemed necessary for the public interest and systemic risk assessment. Different reporting requirements may be set based on the types or sizes of private funds advised. Investment advisers must maintain records of private funds for specified periods as prescribed by the Commission for investor protection and public interest. The Commission may conduct periodic examinations of private fund records maintained by registered investment advisers for investor protection. Investment advisers must provide copies of records to the Commission upon request. The Commission will share information with the Federal Reserve Board. The Commission will share private fund information with the Federal Reserve Board and other entities for assessing systemic risk. Investment advisers must provide reports to investors, counterparties, and creditors of private funds. The Commission will not disclose reports or information filed by investment advisers with the Commission under this subsection, except as required by law. This does not prevent disclosure to Congress, other federal agencies, or courts. The court order in a US action brought by the United States or the Commission is considered a statute for section 552 of title 5, US Code. SEC. 5 eliminates a disclosure provision in the Investment Advisers Act of 1940. SEC. 6 provides an exemption for venture capital fund advisers from registration requirements. SEC. 7 offers an exemption for certain private fund advisers. Section 203 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to provide an exemption from registration requirements for investment advisers of private funds with assets under management in the US of less than $150,000,000. These exempted advisers must maintain records and provide necessary reports to the Commission. Additionally, regulations will be prescribed for mid-sized private fund advisers. The Commission will consider the size, governance, and investment strategy of mid-sized private funds to assess systemic risk and establish registration and examination procedures for their investment advisers based on the level of risk posed by the funds. SEC. 8. CLARIFICATION OF RULEMAKING AUTHORITY. Section 211 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to grant the Commission authority to make rules and regulations, classify persons and matters based on various criteria, prescribe different requirements, and assign different meanings to terms. The Commission is granted authority to make rules, classify persons and matters, prescribe requirements, and assign meanings to terms. The Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission will jointly establish rules for reports filed by investment advisers registered under both the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 and the Commodity Exchange Act. Advisers registered under the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 and the Commodity Exchange Act. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study to assess the costs on industry members and investors due to registration and reporting requirements. A report will be submitted to Congress within 2 years. SEC. 10 of the Act states that it will take effect for investment advisers after a 1-year transition period. The Securities and Exchange Commission will provide rules for advisers to register before the effective date. SEC. 11 introduces the Qualified Client Standard. SEC. 11 introduces the Qualified Client Standard, requiring the Commission to adjust for inflation every 5 years for any dollar amount test used in making determinations under the Investment Advisers Act of 1940.
